7 December 1961
Dear Sam,
Sorry for the delay in responding to your letter of
November l£, but T had to be out In Berkeley and Palo Alto
and simply was unable to effectively keep up with any of
my recent correspondence*
In principle, I believe that in Bill flarley's notion of
an rAEB-sa netioned Audience Survey Research organization
there appear to be several problems that such an organi¬
zation would face* First of all, as T pointed out in my
paper that appeared in the MAEB Journal on the Rating
Services, even a group of educators involved in audience
research might very well encounter the same problems in
1) the uncontrollable problem in operational aspects in
conducting television surveys and 2) the possible biased
uses of such results by stations, advertising agencies,
or whoever is footing the bill. However, I would be
happy to explore further the possibilities of Bill Harley's
notion, since any attempt toward "clearing the air" in the
television research audience area should be carefully con¬
sidered*
?3y the way, our current Title VII Project is revealing some
fascinating data* Our factor analysis particularly gave us
some unusual insights* As I promised, T will send you a
copy of the final report as soon as it is completed.
Keep in touch (hope we can get together one of these days
S OOXl) t
Cordially yours,
